metadata.title: Detection of Bovine Coronavirus in Healthy and Diarrheic Dairy Calves

abstract.original_text: Background: BCoV is identified in both healthy and diarrheic calves, complicating its assessment as a primary pathogen. Objectives: To investigate the detection rates of bovine coronavirus (BCoV) in feces of healthy and diarrheic calves and to describe the usefulness of a pancoronavirus reverse transcriptase (RT) PCR (PanCoV-RT-PCR) assay to identify BCoV in samples of diarrheic calves.

sentences.segment_text: Background : BCoV is identified in both healthy and diarrheic calves ,
complicating its assessment as a primary pathogen .

Objectives : To investigate the detection rates of bovine coronavirus ( BCoV ) in feces of healthy and diarrheic calves and to describe the usefulness of a pancoronavirus reverse transcriptase ( RT ) PCR ( PanCoV-RT-PCR ) assay to identify BCoV in samples of diarrheic calves .

abstract.original_text: Animals: Two hundred and eighty-six calves <21 days. Calves with liquid or semiliquid feces, temperature >39.5°C, and inappetence were considered as cases, and those that had pasty or firm feces and normal physical examination were designated as controls.

sentences.segment_text: Animals : Two hundred and eighty-six calves < 21 days .
Calves with liquid or semiliquid feces ,
temperature > 39.5 °C , and inappetence were considered as cases ,
and those that had pasty or firm feces and normal physical examination were designated as controls .

abstract.original_text: Methods: Prospective case-control study. A specific BCoV-RT-PCR assay was used to detect BCoV in fecal samples. Association between BCoV and health status was evaluated by exact and random effect logistic regression. Fecal (n = 28) and nasal (n = 8) samples from diarrheic calves were tested for the presence of BCoV by both the PanCoV-RT-PCR and a specific BCoV-RT-PCR assays. A Kappa coefficient test was used to assess the level of agreement of both assays.

sentences.segment_text: A specific BCoV-RT-PCR assay was used to detect BCoV in fecal samples .
Association between BCoV and health status was evaluated by exact and random effect logistic regression .
Fecal ( n = 28 ) and nasal ( n = 8 ) samples from diarrheic calves were tested for the presence of BCoV by both the PanCoV-RT-PCR and a specific BCoV-RT-PCR assays .
A Kappa coefficient test was used to assess the level of agreement of both assays .

abstract.original_text: Results: BCoV was detected in 55% (157/286) of calves; 46% (66/143), and 64% (91/143) of healthy and diarrheic calves, respectively. Diarrheic calves had higher odds of BCoV presence than healthy calves (OR: 2.16, 95% CI: 1.26 to 3.83, P = 0.004). A good agreement between PanCoV-RT-PCR and BCoV-RT-PCR to detect BCoV was identified (j = 0.68, 95% CI: 0.392 to 0.967; P < 0.001).

sentences.segment_text: Results : BCoV was detected in 55 % ( 157/286 ) of calves ; 46 % ( 66/143 ) ,
and 64 % ( 91/143 ) of healthy and diarrheic calves , respectively .
Diarrheic calves had higher odds of BCoV presence than healthy calves ( OR : 2.16 , 95 % CI : 1.26 to 3.83 , P = 0.004 ) .
A good agreement between PanCoV-RT-PCR and BCoV-RT-PCR to detect BCoV was identified ( j = 0.68 , 95 % CI : 0.392 to 0.967 ; P < 0.001 ) .

abstract.original_text: Conclusions and Clinical Importance: BCoV was more likely to be detected in diarrheic than healthy calves. The PanCoV-RT-PCR assay can be a useful tool to detect CoV samples from diarrheic calves.

sentences.segment_text: Conclusions and Clinical Importance : BCoV was more likely to be detected in diarrheic than healthy calves .
The PanCoV-RT-PCR assay can be a useful tool to detect CoV samples from diarrheic calves .
